contents.context:
On the first day of shopping with their government relief funds, many people hit their local convenience stores to pick up daily necessities.

"I'm doing my shopping at the convenience store because it's easy to get to and convenient. I'm going to buy feminine products and snacks, which I need now and will always need in the future."

Topping people's shopping lists were rice, sanitary pads, shampoos and diapers.
In fact, sales of rice at convenience stores jumped over 48 percent on Wednesday from the previous day.

"Customers are buying instant rice in packs and looking to buy more expensive products like bluetooth earphones. I think people are spending the money freely because it's not going to sit in their bank accounts forever."

People also went on shopping sprees at convenience stores for items that are normally more expensive there.
Sales of razors for shaving rose well over 70 percent.
And normally slow sellers like wine and ginseng sticks also jumped by double digits.

"The relief money is available for everyone in the country. So people are buying not only necessities but also things that they have been eyeing for a while."

Restaurants and food franchises, on the other hand, have seen no significant rise in sales, apparently because the aid distribution has only just begun.
The recent cluster infection linked to nightclubs has also stopped people from going to and eating at crowded places.

"From Monday to Thursday this week, almost 8 million households have applied for the funds. They'll have the end of August to spend it, so local consumption will see an increase, brightening up local markets over the next few months.
Kim Dami, Arirang News."
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Koreans spending gov't relief funds on necessities and luxuries
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:07:37 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's airlines industry is reporting a massive loss for the first quarter with international travel at a standstill.
The nations's biggest carrier, Korean Air, saw an operating loss of almost 46 million U.S. dollars.
Its sales came to some 1.9-1 billion dollars, down almost 23 percent compared to the same period last year.
The nation's second-biggest carrier, Asiana Airlines saw its operating loss widen to some 169 million dollars and its sales were down over 21 percent on-year.
T'way Air saw an operating loss of around 18 million dollars, and Jin Air saw an operating loss of 25 million dollars.
The full impact of the pandemic only began in March, so analysts expect more losses in the second quarter.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
South Korean airlines suffer operating losses in Q1 2020 due to COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:05:37 KST

contents.context:
A new report says COVID-19 is likely to cost the global economy up to 8.8 trillion U.S. dollars.
According to the Asian Development Bank, the range will be from 5.8 trillion to 8.8 trillion, which is equivalent to six to almost 10 percent of the global GDP.
That's a sharp increase from last month's report, which projected a cost of 2 trillion to 4.1 trillion dollars.
The report says China alone could lose as much as 1.6 trillion.
The ADB, however, said governments around the world can take measures to reduce these losses to a little over 5 trillion dollars.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Global economy could suffer as much as US$ 8.8 tril. in losses due to COVID-19 impact: ADB
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:04:38 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's finance ministry says COVID-19 poses growing downside risks to the local economy.
The ministry's monthly green book released on Friday says weaker consumption has taken a toll on jobs and exports continued to fall.
The number of people employed last month fell by some 480-thousand, the most in over 20 years.
The green book shows credit and debit card spending was down in April by 5.7 percent on year, hitting department stores and discount shops alike.
There was also a collapse, of course, in the number of tourists from China.
Things are stabilizing somewhat in Korea, but the ministry says concerns linger over the downturn globally.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean economy faces increasing downside risks due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-15 13:20:25 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news on this Friday.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Mr. Daniel Yoo, global strategist at Yuanta Securities.
Mr. Yoo, thank you for making time today.

Thank you.

Wall Street recovered some of its recent losses overnight, the Dow up by 1.6 percent. What's the story in the global markets?

Korean stocks seemed to take their cue from Wall Street, starting out higher, but those gains were more subdued by the close. Tell us about the local market.

Stocks were up, but so is gold, considered to be a safe haven. Why is that, and where do you see gold going from here?



Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-15 13:19:58 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's import and export prices both fell last month
The Bank of Korea says import prices dropped over 5-percent on-month in April due to falling global oil prices.
The average price of Dubai crude -- South Korea's benchmark -- was around 20 U.S. dollars a barrel last month, down almost 40 percent on month.
Export prices were 1.6 percent lower during the same period on the falling prices of chemical and petrochemical goods.
On-year, export prices were down almost six percent.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's import and export prices fell in April: BOK
Updated: 2020-05-15 10:05:40 KST

contents.context:
Trade and investment leaders from the G20 are standing together in the face of the coronavirus and its impact on the global economy.
South Korea's trade ministry says the officials of the G20 countries vowed to work together to mitigate the economic impact of the virus, and endorsed several response measures-- during their second extraordinary virtual Trade and Investment Ministerial Meeting on Thursday.
Those measures include the formalization of trade to make trade regulations more transparent, as well as improvements to the World Trade Organization over the longer term.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
G20 trade ministers promise cooperation to ease COVID-19 impact
Updated: 2020-05-15 10:05:30 KST

contents.context:
The New York Stock Exchange will reopen its trading floor on May 26th, but only to some floor brokers first.
Stock exchange president Stacey Cunningham told the Wall Street Journal Thursday that only a "subset of floor brokers" wearing face masks will be allowed back on the trading floor with new stricter safety measures.
The exchange has been operating through all-electronic trading since March 23rd after an employee and a trader tested positive for COVID-19.
Cunningham said that despite the reopening, the majority of traders will still work from home.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
NYSE to reopen trading floor on May 26th with only "subset of floor brokers"
Updated: 2020-05-15 09:57:56 KST

contents.context:
The coronavirus pandemic provided some of South Korea's major food companies a welcome earnings surprise.
CJ Cheiljedang's profits for the first quarter rose over 54-percent on-year.
Orion's profits rose by over 25-percent, thanks to a surge in sales of snacks and protein products.
Samyang Food also saw its profits jumped 73-percent.
Analysts say global panic buying led to a spike in demand for Ramyeon.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Earnings surprise to S. Korean food firms due to COVID-19 food buying
Updated: 2020-05-15 06:00:39 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's Daewoo Engineering and Construction, together with its joint venture partners, has clinched a 4.2 billion U.S. dollar deal to build a liquefied gas plant in Nigeria.
Daewoo E&C said its consortium with Italy's Saipem SPA and Japan's Chiyoda Corporation will construct the so-called 'Train 7' project for Nigeria LNG.
The plant will be able to produce 8-million tons of LNG and should be completed five-and-a-half years after breaking ground.
Daewoo says it has a roughly 40 percent stake in the consortium.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Daewoo E&C's multinational consortium wins US$ 4.2 bil. LNG plant deal in Nigeria
Updated: 2020-05-15 06:00:33 KST

contents.context:
As the United States is pressing hard to reopen its economy, the stock market too, says it will partially reopen this month.
This just coming a little while ago, the New York Stock Exchange saying it will reopen the trading floor starting May 26th with 'vital new safety measures' in place.
And for your market closings on Thursday.
Stocks on Wall Street rebounded as bank shares offset another gloomy jobless claims report.
An extra 3 million Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week alone, pushing the total number of first-time claimants to 36-and-a-half million since mid-March.
Despite that, the Dow Jones closed up over one-and-a-half percent, the S&P 500, over one-percent and the NASDAQ picked up around the same percentage amount.
Crude oil prices went up on a dip in U.S. crude stockpiles -- and after the International Energy Agency forecast lower global stockpiles in the latter half of 2020.
Brent Crude was up 7-percent and WTI rose near 10-percent to close at 27-dollars 76-cents.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
NYSE to partially reopen on May 26 after two month closure
Updated: 2020-05-15 06:00:31 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government announced on Thursday plans to create a total of 1.five-six million jobs in the public sector, of which, around 765-thousand are new jobs.
The announcement comes just one day after figures showed the steepest job losses for the month of April in more than 20 years.

"The coronavirus outbreak is causing massive shocks and changes to the number and quality of jobs in the labor market, along with immediate job losses. Emergency employment measures are urgently needed."

The government expects some 765-thousand new jobs to be created.
It will resume the hiring process for some 48-thousand public officials and jobs in public institutions this month.
Young people directly hit by the pandemic will also have more opportunities through plans to create more than 550-thousand additional jobs in non-contact and digital sectors.
In the budget for this year, the government had planned to create 945-thousand jobs, and some 167-thousand of those will be added in May and June.
Officials plan to finalize the specific measures during next week's economic meeting, and draw up the required funds from a planned third coronavirus-related supplementary budget.
But an expert says more needs to be done to encourage hiring by private businesses.

"It's good that the government is drawing funds to create more jobs in the public sector. But it's more important to let private firms lead the economy, rather than the government taking the lead. The government could take extra measures, like reducing corporate taxes, leading companies to hire more and invest more."

"Both the public and private sectors will have to create jobs to overcome this employment crisis, but the government's measure can be seen as a positive step toward tackling the most torrid period that jobseekers have seen in years.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News."
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gov't to create total of 1.56 million public sector jobs: Finance Minister
Updated: 2020-05-14 17:14:45 KST
